So today is the 26th of September 2019. This is Dr. Adiola Dowis. Can you say your full
name?
My full name is Carlton Peets.
Carlton Peets. And where were you born?
St. Kitts, the best island in the Caribbean.
And what is your birth date?
What were your parents' names?
My parents was married to make a street. My mother was Vivian Peets. My father was Izzy
Gale Sutton, which is also my middle name.
Izzy?
E-Z-K-I-E-L.
Ezekiel.
Yeah, just like in the Bible.
Okay. And what did they do for a living?
Well, at the time there wasn't much job for their kind of education. My mother used to
be a king and my father cut them.
Oh, okay. And did you have brothers and sisters?
Yes. Four sisters and one brother.
And where are you in the...
In the middle. I'm the fourth out of the six.
Okay. And what was growing up in St. Kitts like? What do you remember?
Well, growing up in St. Kitts, I was very, very happy. We have everything, sports, all
the... I mean, go to the mountain and do everything boys do.
What was school like? Did you like school?
Oh, yes. Not at first. But first, when I started, I used to like going down to see water. And
once my sister came to look for me, that I didn't feel like going to school. And she
got a joy cane because we had a lot of sugar canes in St. Kitts. But one field was there
barren. And she took up one of those and every time she walked and she catch up to me, it's
a good thing. And unfortunately, my classroom was outside the school. I was in what they
call outside class, put it away. And when I turned around the corner, I saw my class
outside and I started drawing my eyes because I didn't want them to know that I got licks
to go to school. And then went in school, my sister knew the teacher and she said,
I could tell you her name now, Clarice. She named Clarice Canes. And my sister said, Clarice,
could you mark him present for me? She said, oh yes, I will. And then with this time, just
everybody else moving out, she called me back and she said, your sister didn't send you
her name. I said, who tell you so? And she said, and she put her hand across my forehead
and she wiped off the salt so that when you wipe off the salt, you know you was down the
sea. Because he left his mark. And then she told me, I won't mention the words she told
me as a teacher, but she said, next time you run away from school again without any
permission, I'll startle myself. I mean that was nice, soft words she told me, but it didn't
like that she told me. But you did enjoy school. Oh yes, after that morning, first man in school
is me. First person in school from that episode was me. And Taylor reached seventh standard.
Then I had a little, well I used to do what they call gardening and go to school. So my
boss was a white man, he named me Mr. Ball. This is after you left school? No, before,
while I'm going to school, go to work in the morning, well there's a little garden, just
water the plants and pick out any little weeds. Because if you pick out the weeds every day,
you won't have much to do. So you water the garden and go to school in the morning and
after school you go back in the afternoon. Then the boss and the mistress fall in love
with me, so they give me everything. They used to treat me like their own son or children
because they had three children. So I was one of the Balls. Black Ball. Yeah, so. Okay,
so what kinds of things did you want to be when you grew up at that age? Did you have
any dreams? I didn't have much dream, but I know for a fact I wasn't going in the cane
field to work. That's for a fact. Because I always say if my mother weed them and my
father cut them, there's no place there for me. So. Did you see it as a very hard job?
Cutting the cane? Oh yes. Oh yes. And they were, they wasn't paid the right rate and
everything through politics and so on. And I'll tell you what, the man who was in charge
was a blacker man than me. All the days only black and black, but he was really black.
And he was in charge of everything. Negotiation with the Prime Minister Robert Llewellyn Bratcher.
Was Sunkist at that time very segregated? Yes, I will say yes because I mean you never
used to see black people working in a bank and so on. And if you want a high job, let's
say working down for government, you have to go to grammar school which was the high
school in the land at the moment. So unless you go to grammar school you know you can't
get a good job. So you just have to take the menial jobs what left. Was it easy for black
children to go to grammar school? No. No because I mean you have the, what's the name? The
what's it called? I can't remember exactly what you call it. But then if you're bright
enough and you could pass the entrance fee, the entrance fee is that your parents will
have to pay for you. Like me, I could have passed the entrance fee but my head teacher
Mrs. Williams went and asked my father which he could afford to because his cousin was
paying for one of his sons to go to the same school. And he said no. Why did he say no?
Well, just like most West Indian fathers, they forget their children just grew up. And
he said no. And he told Mrs. Williams straight, he's only my mother, but at that time you
know we used to talk like we were speaking. He said we're only my mother you know and
I can't do it. And she was a bit gutted. And like a friend of mine who was in the same
class, he went to grammar school because he passed the, oh god I can't remember what
it is now. And a friend, the other friend of mine who was, he went to Convent School
and that one, one end up as an engineer and the other one was the chief accountant in
one of the banks in St. Kitts. And me, just left behind. So that's why as I said to you
early on, after I got that job and the man told me to go and sell myself, I said to myself,
no way, I'm not looking for more work, I'm not filling out nothing.
What job is this? You mean the gardening?
No, no, it was just caretaker of the arms, caretaker supervisor, you know and then was
in charge of the cleaners and so on. But there again there was a lot of prejudice in that
as well too.
So after you left school you got that job as an accountant?
No, well just before I came from St. Kitts to here, I used to work in the batter, batter
shoe store.
Oh.
Oh yes, as the, what's it called it now, the, of course, as a young man, I was a young

used to clean out the store. His name was Vernon Twelves, you know.
So what was the decision to come to the UK?
Well, it was a tough decision. First that if it was left to my mother, I want to be
but through my sister was here, my oldest sister, I had a choice. She was going to send
for me and I could get a job down the health center as, what do you call him now, sanitary
inspector. I would have got that job because it was already earmarked for me. Yeah, because
through friends and so on and through us, I'm not, I was a nice boy growing up. My people,
well, some, I won't say friends, but elderly people who know the man, they tell him and
so on and a good word, very good word. So it was like this, which I would come first
at the end of the month. If the money come first, which I explained to the man in here,
Mr. Buchanan, he was in charge. Said, Mr. Buchanan, if the money come first before the
ending of the month, I'll be going to England. If you don't, I won't be going to England,
I'll take the job. And unfortunately or fortunately, the money came first. And then as I said,
it came to my sister. What were you expecting? What did you think of England before you knew
about it, before you came here? Well, be honest with you, you always say England, do this
England, is that an England? The East African women were saying England pay with gold and
streets pay with gold and all them sort of nonsense. But then when you look at the, some
of the West Indian readers, what they used to send for us. You see cows going up pushing,
pushing cow up the ladder instead of going up on the roof to cut the grass. Well, I mean,
as Barber said, there was fooling us. And then they get some other West Indian book,
I think it's visual English books and that was a different scenario to the old West Indian
books. So in school they were actually teaching you propaganda? Well, that was the English
teaching. And you were still a colony, Sunkets were still a colony? Yes. So when you came
over, you were on a British passport? That's right. So you were British? British, yes.
Well, I still put down British up to now. And how did you travel? Did you come by boat
or by boat? Both. I flew from Sunkets to Antigua, from Antigua to Trinidad. And then
we caught the boat in Trinidad. It was about a good 20 of us from Sunkets that day. A woman,
she had about six children with her and me and my friends and so on. Do you remember
the boat? No, I can't remember it. I tried to look for it at Scania or something like
that, but I can't remember it rightly so I won't tell you. Do you remember the journey?
Well, the most I can remember is when we were in Trinidad. We had a good time in Trinidad.
As boys, you know, we went up and down the place. And because there was a few more boys
joined from Dominica, they were from Dominica with us in Trinidad. So, you know, boys will
be discussing as usual. And you used to have some good times. This woman on the boat, she
could speak Spanish. So everything we want, we ask her. Well, she knew me as well and
she knew my parents. So you only ask her to feel like chicken today, feel like fish today
and she will order whatever you ask her to. So the boat, the crew was Spanish speaking?
Yes, but they could speak English as well. Okay. And do you remember anything else about
the journey? Was it a happy journey? Well, as I said, it was happy because some of us
were, especially this fellow from Dominica, I mean, we were supposed to be, let's say,
on the lower deck. He carried me all up on the top deck and everything and foolish me
for him. Even though we were wrong or not supposed to be, we were still going. So before
I came up here, you know, I was discussing it. How long were you? How long were you?
I can't even remember. I think around that. Around 20 years old? Yeah. And when did you
come? So what was it like when you arrived? Well, we went to Madrid. We landed in Madrid
in Spain. And my friend is leaning over the railing for the ship because I leave from
Spain to come to Cardiff by train. But leaning over the railing, you see people. Oh no, for
now from Spain, we leave from Spain to Southampton. And then you see some people, when the Spanish
women, well, I mean, they were more or less dressed in black as well. And when you see
them speaking, you see steam coming out of their mouth. So when I tell my friend, look
at them, steam coming out of their mouth, he says, you too. I said, you too. So you
came in winter perhaps? Yes, it was in February I came here. What were you wearing, do you
remember? Were you ready for the weather? No. Funny enough, I had a cardigan that I
brought from home because that was only for style, really, because in the West End you
don't need them. So luckily I wore it. What color was the cardigan? I think roughly was
red and black. Red, white and black. Yeah, white was up here, red up here, white in the
middle and black down here. Could always remember that. So what was your first impression of
Britain? So you saw the coal coming out of the mouth and when you step out, what was
it like for you? Well, we stay on the ship and then we came to Southampton and then we
land in Southampton. Well, me, all on my own. I don't know nobody. So I asked a man, look,
he was very polite and kind and he said, oh, I'll go up the rail and drop you up the
road. Well, on hindsight now, I think I was taking a chance because I don't know the people,
I don't know the place, so he couldn't go anywhere with me or whatever because he was
a man, he was a boy. So, you know, took the chance but I mean everything worked out to
the end and he said, if you don't know what to do, ask any one of them people, they in
black, like the porters on the railway. And then? Then come to Cardiff. How come you came
to Cardiff? Is that where your sister was? Yes. And why did she come to Cardiff? Why
Cardiff? Well, I thought, my home father is one half pay for her, so when they say half,
I wouldn't like to elaborate too much on that part of it. But let's say for convenience
sake, my father sent four. Okay, and he was here already? Yes. Okay, so you already had
a crew waiting for you? No, nobody was waiting for me. I had to find my way from the train
station to South Church Street. You know where South Church Street is? What was that like?
Well, then on my way almost out of the train station, my brother and brother-in-law turned
up. So they helped me. We walked down the back canal, you know, and then come down the
back. And then the first person I met was a friend, a fellow. He was much older than
me. And he used to, when we were in the grammar school, we played sports and so on. And Sunday
school time coming up, and we don't go. He'd call us. Come on, you had to go Sunday school,
because Sunday school. But then when I look, the man had a big long cigarette in his mouth.
I said, well, cook, you don't do names like that. As a Christian, he said, boy, it's a
different story over here, you know. Was he from St. Kitts as well? Yes, yeah. Well, and
he was a good cook eater too. And then more or less, you could say I learned from him.
Did you find the transition easy? So you came to Butown? Yes. Did you find the transition
easy from, besides the weather, from St. Kitts to Butown? Yes, because I mean, almost not
good. It was okay for me, because nobody really used to bother me or something like
that. And I had a friend. His brother was here as well. Well, you might know him, what
we call Dexter. Well, many grew up from the same village. And so I had a, you could say
a friend, so we could correspond with each other.
What was Butown like at that time? So you didn't have to go to school at that age? No.
What did you do? I had to work. Soon as I came, I had to get the first job. But as I
said, I won't go into the details, because it might be embarrassing for somebody else.
Okay. So roughly, was it easy to get a job? At the time, no. The most jobs you'll get
are factory jobs, because my brother-in-law was working down the post office. I applied
for a job down there, and they told me they'll let me know. I'm still waiting for them to
let me know. About a year or so ago, I found a letter, but in vexation, I ripped it up,
I think. The guy said, look, they're supposed to let me know, and they're supposed to be
this and that. So. Was it like that? Was that a common thing? Going for different jobs and
them saying they'll get back to you and not getting back to you? Well, as I said, I didn't
have too many jobs, but those that I really went for, I got. So, I mean, first job I refused.
Was a place named John Williams over East Mores, and the place they wanted me to work
where they had vacancy is a place they call Knockout, the Knockout. The Knockout is like
a furnace. I just come from the West Indies, I'm hot already. I mean, let's say up there
in the center, the furnace down here, and I'm sweating. I said, no, thanks. And then
when I went to a place named Super Oil Seals, got a job there. Then after about 11, 12 years
or so, I pack up Super Oil Seals and went to the skill center. We learned welding. And
after about a year or so, place over there, my sense, they used to make radiators and
they fold up. So then I was working for nearly three years. And then, as I said, I used to
come to the center often, and the aviator named John Winslet, this morning, he sent
an application in the Western Mail, and he got one for me. And he called me and he told
me, here, as I said to you before, here you are now, go and sell yourself, fill out the
form. And after filling out the form, I said, Mr. Winslet, could you look at it for me and
see? He said, why, no. Because if you make a mistake, you're going to say it's true me,
but you ain't get the job. And as I said to you, the only form, I mean, internally in
this council, because of the housing department, I did apply for different jobs. And I passed
them, but especially the last one was to be like the, what's it called, over Nelson House
here. And after the lot, well, you might know some university people did apply as well too,
but some of them was too qualified. So I got the job, because of the rest who left,
I had the best specification of the rest. But what you think happened? My boss, she
named Blondwin Lloyd, she gave it to one of her friends. And she said, I'm going to

Okay. All right. So in terms of the challenges you faced being here so far, so you had the ones with
work, you know, were there any other main challenges that you experienced being here to where you are now?
I don't know how to explain that. But I know, well, I was lucky in a sense because we form a cricket
team because when they came here first, they had a Bajoran cricket team they called Spartans. And at
the time, well, you could see in my photograph, I was skinny. And when they were playing some,
let's say a side, I mean the team or the club had picked two sides. And this fellow left them
and went to play for somebody else. But he was a Bajoran. And the fellow looked around and he
said, I look the smallest. He said, I'm serious. Now he tell me go off the field. And then me and
my brother-in-law came up. And as I said, we live in South Church Street. And, you know, it was right
by the church. This club named Spartan, not Spartan, Combine was having a meeting because they were just
farming as well. And went in there and they invited me with open arms and I went and we joined
that. And I played for Combine and we got a few more kitties and so on because it was
more or less kitties who were farming. And then we get a good side, put it away. And we used to
beat everybody. And then we didn't have much more challenges. So some of us broke away. And then we
had a better team then, a better club. We called it Progressive. And Progressive was a team we know
from St. Kitts. That's why we gave it that name. And some of the Bajorans who was in
the club, the Spartans and so on, came and joined us. And well, I was the club secretary,
treasurer secretary. And I was lucky enough. I met another, I think she born here,
she come from St. Kitts Little. Sure you might know, Donna Lyburn. No, she's in London now.
She used to work, well funny enough she and my wife used to work in David Morgan's.
And then she went and she started working for the Bay, Cardiff Bay, you know that. And
every year used to get grants for the cricket club and so on. So we was, you could say successful.
And then I was the first black man that got to say please get a cricket pitch
for our club. It overfits Allen.
The head of Cardiff Bay at the time was a man named Mr. Inking. And Mr. Inking did like cricket
so he used to go down there and we talk and talk and talk and you know he get his people
who used to work in Victoria Park. You know they do gardening and so on. And they fix up the pitch
first and then some people you know at the parts of the club think they know it all.
And when they start saying they know it all, I leave it all to them and I pull away.
But as I said you could say from the trophy when we when we joined the cricket club we joined
Cardiff Midweek League Division 4. And every year we promote from four, three, two,
till we become the champions. Even before we become champions we was beating the champions.
And then we joined the Morgana Cricket League and they put us Division 5.
And we work ourselves right up to champions as well. So we had a good good successful local
cricket team. And he said we used to have two and three trophies every year.
